    Madeiras Cove beach closed to swimmers

    July 9, 2014
    0

Oak Bluffs health agent Shirley Fauteaux closed the beach in Madeiras Cove, near the Sailing Camp in Lagoon Pond on Tuesday, after a water sample showed higher than allowable bacteria counts.
column34:
A sample taken during routine testing Monday showed 278 colonies of enterococci bacteria. Under state regulations, a beach must be closed to swimmers if the count exceeds 104 colonies per 100 milliliters of water.

Enterococci is a bacteria that signals the presence of other dangerous bacteria is in the water.

Ms. Fauteaux said she will test the water again on Wednesday, and if the results are within acceptable limits, she will reopen Madeiras Cove on Thursday.
column37:
The Massachusetts Bureau of Environmental Health advises that swimming in polluted water can cause gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, respiratory symptoms such as sore throat, cough, runny nose, and sneezing, eye and ear symptoms including irritation, earache, and itchiness, dermatological symptoms like skin rash and itching, and flu-like symptoms such as fever and chills.

Most of these symptoms are minor most of the time, but they can occasionally be more serious, especially in sensitive populations such as those with weakened immune systems, children, and the elderly.

column1: For the fourth time since early June, the beach at Beltzville State Park near Lehighton has been closed to swimmers due to a high bacterial count.

The Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources closed the beach today, based on water samples from Monday. It will remain closed until acceptable samples are received, the agency said in a press release.
The beach also was closed June 5, June 13 and July 2 due to high bacteria. In all three cases, it reopened a few days later.
Signs have been posted at the beach informing park visitors of the closing.
Other activities at Beltzville, such as picnicking, fishing, boating and hiking, are proceeding as usual.

Boil water order issued in Highwood

<div class=""trb_ar_la""><aside class=""trb_em"" data-content-id=""68267570"" data-content-size=""leadart"" data-content-slug=""chi-lake-county-image"" data-content-subtype=""photo"" data-content-type=""image"" data-role=""sc_item imgsize_ratiosizecontainer"" data-state="""">
Gregory TrotterTribune reporter

Residents of northern Highwood are under an advisory boil water order after water was shut off for hours last night for emergency repairs on broken water mains, Highwood officials said.

Though no contaminants have been found in the water supply, the city issued the advisory order to protect against the ""very unlikely"" risk of contamination, said City Manager Scott Hartman. The boil order covers those living north of Washington Avenue and west of Green Bay Road.

The water main breaks occurred Tuesday near Euclid Avenue and Euclid Court, Hartman said, and may have been the result of flow testing on the fire hydrants affecting the old water pipes.

Both water mains were repaired by 9 p.m. Tuesday, Hartman said.

“We were very pleased with our public works crew,” Hartman said. “Our initial concern was whether we could get them fixed by this morning.”

Highwood treats it own water, which is drawn from Lake Michigan. Today, water samples are being collected for testing in neighboring Highland Park’s lab, Hartman said. The results will be known by Thursday morning.

Once the samples are confirmed clear of contaminants, the boil order will be lifted, he said.

Until then, any water used for consumption should be boiled.

<section class=""story-body inner""><div class=""originBylineContainer""><div class=""image-caption global-caption wabc byline"">

WABC
Saturday, July 12, 2014
BLOOMFIELD, N.J. (WABC) --
It is now safe to drink and use tap water in Bloomfield Township, according to officials.

Authorities sent out a notice Saturday afternoon that the water now complies with all safe drinking water standards.

E. coli bacteria were found in water supply samples collected Monday in Bloomfield. These bacteria can make you sick, and are a particular concern for people with weakened immune systems.

Bacterial contamination can occur when increased run-off enters the drinking water source (for example, following heavy rains). It can also happen due to a break in the distribution system (pipes) or a failure in the water treatment process.

All water had to be boiled for one minute, then cooled before use for drinking, making ice, brushing teeth, washing dishes, and food preparation until further notice. Boiling kills bacteria and other organisms in the water.

When the advisory was first sent, the township said it would take corrective actions including chlorinating, flushing, additional sampling and assessing the Bloomfield system as well as investigating sampling procedures, residual disinfectant levels, and source water quality. Bloomfield is a consecutive system supplied by Newark Water Department.

For more information, please contact Bloomfield Water Department Licensed Operator Anthony Marucci at (973) 680-4009.

Jamesville Beach closed for swimming

by Corey Crockett
column2:
body=You%20should%20read%20this!%0A%0Ahttp://cnycentral.com/news/local/jamesville-beach-closed-for-swimming"">
Wed, 09 Jul 2014 20:09:16 GMT — 



Jamesville Beach is closed for swimmers after the Onondaga County Health Department determined that bacteria levels in the water were above normal.


Swimming will not be allowed until the bacteria levels return to acceptable levels.


The Health Department says that most varieties of E.coli are harmless or cause brief symptoms, but high levels of E. coli are usually indicators of other bacteria levels that are higher than normal.

Biltmore, Philip Healey beaches in Massapequa closed to swimming
Seagulls cruise in formation off Philip B. Healey Beach off Florence Avenue in Massapequa. Photo Credit: Newsday/David L. Pokress
By ROSEMARY OLANDER  rosemary.olander@newsday.com Updated July 9, 2014 3:29 PM
Tweet
Share
Email
Biltmore and Philip Healey beaches, both in Massapequa, were closed to swimming Wednesday because of elevated levels of bacteria, according to a Nassau County Department of Health news release.
All other Nassau County beaches operating for the 2014 season are currently open, the department said.
For recorded information on beach closings and openings in Nassau, call 516-227-9700. Health department representatives are available weekdays, from 9 a.m. to 4:45 p.m., at 516-227-9717.
